name: Dividing unit fractions by whole numbers

skills.name: Divide proper fractions in the form: Fraction ÷ Integer
Dividing unit fractions by an integer using a bar model and fact families
Dividing a unit fraction by an integer

explanations.A: We do want 1 block, but how big is this considering the whole bar is worth 1/6?
explanations.B: This is 1/5 of the shape, but it is 1/5 of 1/6. What operation do we use for this?
explanations.C: I think you have seen it is 1/5 of the shape. When we are finding 1/5 of 1/6 we don't add the denominators. What operation means 'of'?
explanations.D: This problem is showing that 1/6 has been divided by 5, so we need 1/5 of 1/6. This is the same as 1/5 x 1/6 = 1x1/5x6 = 1/30

explanations.A: This is 1/4 of the shape, but it is 1/4 of 1/5. What operation do we use for this?
explanations.B: We do want 1 block, but how big is this considering the whole bar is worth 1/5?
explanations.C: This problem is showing that 1/5 has been divided by 4, so we need 1/4 of 1/5. This is the same as 1/4 x 1/5 = 1x1/4x5 = 1/20
explanations.D: I think you have seen it is 1/4 of the shape. When we are finding 1/4 of 1/5 we don't add the denominators. What operation means 'of'?

explanations.A: Not quite - the bar is already split into thirds, but we want to divide one third by six. How many pieces should we cut each third into?
explanations.B: Not quite - this would be how many pieces in the whole bar after we divide each third into 6. We want to know how many pieces in one third.
explanations.C: Not quite - we're not trying to divide the whole bar into sixths, we're trying to divide 1/3 by 6.
explanations.D: Dividing by 6 means sharing into 6 parts, so we would cut each third into 6 pieces.

explanations.A: Not quite - the bar is already split into thirds, but we want to divide one third by five. How many pieces should we cut each third into?
explanations.B: Dividing by 5 means sharing into 5 parts, so we would cut each third into 5 pieces.
explanations.C: I think you've added the 3 and 5. But, what we need to do is to divide one third by five. How many pieces should we cut each third into, to divide it by 5?
explanations.D: Not quite - this would be how many pieces are in the whole bar after we divide each third into 5. We want to know how many pieces in one third.

explanations.A: The question mark does show one piece out of the whole bar, but how many pieces has the whole bar been split into? That will be the denominator.
explanations.B: The light shading does show 3/9, but we are looking for the dark shading. This is the light section divided into 3 parts, so 3/9 ÷ 3.
explanations.C: The bar is split into thirds, and then each third is split into 3. Altogether there are now 9 equal parts, so 1/3 ÷ 3 = 1/9, as shown by the darker blue shading.
explanations.D: Not quite, this is the light blue shading. We only have one of those 3 pieces, so we need to do 1/3 ÷ 3. You can use the image to work out the size of each of the boxes to do this.

explanations.A: The question mark does show one piece out of the whole bar, but how many pieces has the whole bar been split into? That will be the denominator.
explanations.B: The darker orange section is 1/4 of the whole shaded section. But what fraction is the darker orange section of the whole model?
explanations.C: The whole of the shaded area shows 1/3, but which part of the model shows that third divided into 4?
explanations.D: The bar is split into thirds, and then each third is split into 4. Altogether there are now 12 equal parts, so 1/3 ÷ 4 = 1/12, as shown by the darker orange shading.

explanations.A: Think about an easier example: 5 x 3 = 15, so what is 15 ÷ 3? Can you make the same link in this question?
explanations.B: Close, but I think you might have flipped over the 1/5 and then multiplied by the 4 which isn't quite right... Think about an easier example: 5 x 3 = 15, so what is 15 ÷ 3?
explanations.C: Think about an easier example: 5 x 3 = 15, so what is 15 ÷ 3? Can you make the same link in this question?
explanations.D: The box tells us that there are 4 lots of 1/20 in 1/5, so if we divide 1/5 by 4 we will get back to 1/20.

explanations.A: The box tells us that there are 5 lots of 1/30 in 1/6, so if we divide 1/6 by 5 we will get back to 1/30.
explanations.B: Think about an easier example: 5 x 3 = 15, so what is 15 ÷ 3? Can you make the same link in this question?
explanations.C: Think about an easier example: 5 x 3 = 15, so what is 15 ÷ 3? Can you make the same link in this question?
explanations.D: Not quite, I think you might have flipped over the 1/6 and then multiplied by 5 which isn't quite right... Think about an easier example to see how it works: 5 x 3 = 15, so what is 15 ÷ 3?

explanations.A: Close, but I think you might have flipped over the 1/7 and then multiplied by 4, which isn't quite right... Remember 4 can be written as 4/1, and if you're using the "Keep Flip Change" method it's the second fraction that flips over.
explanations.B: Close, but I think you might have flipped over both fractions and then multiplied - remember if you're using the "Keep Flip Change" method it's the second fraction which flips over.
explanations.D: Close, but remember 4 can be written as 4/1, and if you're using the "Keep Flip Change" method the second fraction needs to be flipped over before you multiply.

explanations.A: Close, but I think you might have flipped over the 1/9 and then multiplied by 6, which isn't quite right... Remember 6 can be written as 6/1, and if you're using the "Keep Flip Change" method it's the second fraction that flips over.
explanations.B: Close, but I think you might have flipped over both fractions and then multiplied - remember if you're using the "Keep Flip Change" method it's the second fraction which flips over.
explanations.C: Close, but remember 6 can be written as 6/1, and if you're using the "Keep Flip Change" method, the second fraction needs to be flipped over before you multiply.
